title: Food and Dining
context: Korean food is world-renowned and incredibly diverse! From kimchi to bibimbap to Korean BBQ, food is a central part of Korean culture. Being able to talk about food and order at restaurants is not only practical but also a great way to immerse yourself in Korean culture.

Did you know? Koreans have a beautiful phrase '잘 먹겠습니다' (jal meokgesseumnida) said before eating, which means 'I will eat well' - a way of showing gratitude for the meal. After eating, you say '잘 먹었습니다' (jal meogeosseumnida) meaning 'I ate well'.

This lesson will equip you with essential food vocabulary and dining phrases. You'll learn how to order food, express your preferences, and use polite expressions at meals - crucial skills for anyone visiting Korea or enjoying Korean cuisine!

sentences.english: I will eat well (said before eating)

explanation: 주세요 (juseyo) is an essential phrase meaning 'please give me'. Use it to order: [item] + 주세요. For example: 커피 주세요 (coffee please).
밥 (bap) literally means 'rice' but is also used to mean 'meal'. 밥 먹었어요? (Did you eat rice?) is a common greeting asking if someone has eaten.
The particle 가/이 marks the subject of a sentence. Use 가 after vowels and 이 after consonants. 김치가 맛있어요 = 'Kimchi is delicious'.
좋아하다 (joahada) means 'to like'. The object of what you like takes the 을/를 particle: 음식을 좋아해요 (I like food).
잘 먹겠습니다 (before eating) and 잘 먹었습니다 (after eating) are polite expressions showing gratitude for the meal. Always use these!
좀 (jom) means 'a little' or 'some' and softens requests. 물 좀 주세요 sounds more polite than just 물 주세요.
